review_title: Biomedical research experience depends on lab
pros: I mostly haven't had to use my healthcare benefits, but I think they are okay? My boss is pretty good about needing to take sick leave, vacation, etc., but some others are not. Housing/cost of living in Dallas is cheaper than in CA or the East coast, but the cost is rising (CA people are coming here). There are some really good labs here.
cons: No maternity leave (people use sick/vacation days or unpaid FMLA). While my boss is pretty good about most things, your experience will vary wildly based on which lab you work in. I have heard horror stories about a few other labs (sexual harassment with no consequence that I know of for the PI/perpetrator; people being made/pressured to work during covid lockdowns, or while they themselves had symptomatic covid; PIs wrongfully removing trainees/employees from publications, etc.). Employees who are on work visas are particularly vulnerable to these abuses, in part because they risk being deported if they are fired or if they quit. Many labs are fine, but some are not, and it seems like as long as the PI's scientific reputation/funding/publication record is good, the university leaves them alone. I'm not sure whether UT Southwestern is an outlier in this respect, or if this situation is common among universities. I have certainly heard stories of abusive PIs in other institutions, but did not hear so many bad stories at my previous university (it's possible I was out of the loop).

review_title: Interesting work, great benefits but low salary, strict working hours
pros: UTSW is a great place to work to be on the leading edge of healthcare. Really interesting work with faculty which are striving to advance medicine and are highly invested to bring their best care for their patients. New facilities which are state of the art, lots of technical support for work, wonderful residents which work very hard and are committed to their specialty. Job specific pros: set work schedule with very little overtime, great co-workers, wonderful patients, and interesting and challenging work. Great benefits: health insurance - UT pays for employee benefits and adding family members is reasonable. Retirement - participates in TRS with employer match and good long-term security. Retirees can keep their health insurance after working at UTSW for a minimum of 10 years. PTO - tiered earnings with longevity beginning at 8hr/month both sick and vacation, plus "flexible holiday" hours and Texas/Federal holidays are days off. Additional benefits which are also generous. Benefits are definitely a pro of working for UT.
cons: Cons: set, rigid work schedule. The "7-minute rule" applies - being later than 7 minutes after your assigned start time is a huge negative. This job is great for someone who likes routine and predictability. However, because you're part of a team and everyone has a significant workload, it's tough to get time away and any deviation from your set schedule requires planning. This is not a job for someone who needs/likes flexibility! Stressful workload: there is always more work than can be reasonably accomplished in 40 hours a week. UT saves on staff costs, so plan to work hard. Low salary: to make up for great benefits, salaries are below industry standards, sometime well below. However, since it's a public entity, you can find salary information online, and can (and should) ask the salary range. Raises are maximum 3-5% per year, with 5% being incredibly exceptional. Plan 3% increase per year with excellent job performance, so your starting salary is crucial. No bonuses. High turnover: because of the low salary and minimal increases, co-workers leave for better opportunities instead of growing within their current job. 100% turnover of non-supervisor positions is normal. Low "fun factor": time away for team building, training, or anything outside of normal job duties is considered a problem. Occasional in-office staff luncheons are about it for "fun".

job_title: Patient Financial Advocate in Dallas, TX
pros: I worked at UT Southwestern for 8 years. I loved the benefits, like free healthcare for employees. Yearly merritt raises.
cons: If you are having Mental Health issues, and are stuggling, UT Southwestern is quite literally the worst place to work for. No support from anyone other than just call EAP and they wipe their hands clean of you. Should you show signs of any mental health issues, my chronic migraines contributed to my depression and I was only on FMLA for the migraines. As soon as my production took a hit from me struggling and not being able to speak to anyone in regards to my issues because the management made sure to take one thing I said and turned it into a fireable offense instead of helping me and proving me with the support I needed. So make sure you keep up with your FMLA and document EVERYTHING. If your management has any video confrences with you, make sure they are recorded. As management will lie if they do not have anything other than your word against theirs. When it is a team of 2 supervisors and the manager who ends up getting promoted to department director they will all stick up for each other, which i can't blame them, the director of the department leads with fear, no mercy, no grace. All their good workers leave and they get repplaced with problematic people who just suck up and rub the director's ego to stay on their "good side." It's ALL politics at UT Southwestern it's not WHAT you know it's WHO you know and WHO's friend you pretend to be. If you are told negative things about a department, LISTEN the reason there are negative things said about those departments is because management is BAD and if you have mental health issues and are in one of "those," departments your mental health will only get worse. People will not leave management that treats them well.

pros: UT offers free medical insurance to the employee and the TRS match is great! There is room for growth if you have the right network.
cons:
They have a lot of room for growth in the diversity department. In every position I held as a minority, I always overlooked and undervalued and subjected to racism.

Examples #1: This specific departments only allowed 1 person off at a time. I was denied time off for close family surgery, due to policy, but my colleagues would repeatedly get approved when others were scheduled off. 

Example #2: Another department had 5 individuals who held the same title and I was the only minority. My colleagues would only need to mark themselves out on the calendar, but it was my responsibility to find my own coverage. I would have to beg others and offer lunch and other favors to get coverage. The manager said that doctors had to find their own coverage for on-call, so this was policy. I was working as a front desk  as receptionist, I don’t think that’s comparable.

Example #3: I overheard a high level executive telling another executive “I don’t think “they” can spell”, near my work area. The other executive then calls me in their office about 10 minutes later and ask me to spell “itinerary”. I answered correctly and they responded, good job - I was drawing a blank. 

Example #4: In another department, I continuously asked for ways to gain more responsibility. I was always told that there wasn’t room for additional work, but I could “clean” the basement if I’m just looking for extra work.

I’d like to note that I’m educated and every role was a promotion, I just wasn’t valued the same as my counterparts. 

It was exhausting working in such a overly bureaucratic organization. I thought long and hard before giving an honest review, but it’s my truth.

pros: None... if you are on the administrative side there aren't any. It's a great place for science, research, and medicine, but terribly outdated with everything else.
cons:
Terrible pay- no bonuses, no merit increases, no stocks.... in other words no incentives. The max increase was 2% for the highest rating possible. A person who barely showed up and didn't do their job got a 1.5% raise... there's no incentive or reason to put in the work so people don't. It's borderline impossible to get fired so people stay there forever and just coast, festering in their incompetence. 

Shockingly terrible benefits for a hospital. Insurance was expensive and not great. 

Retirement plan is a joke- it's through the Teacher's Retirement System or whatever the public one is in Texas. It doesn't allow you to change your contribution %; it's fixed. 

Terrible, over-bearing, green, micro-managing managers. Didn't have actual deliverables; literally their only job was to manage the employees so they were up our butts all the time. 

Did not allow WFH at the time.

job_title: Strategic Sourcing Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: UTSW is a great organization continuously growing. That doesn’t appear it will slow down anytime soon. Do your own research on that. Construction cranes everywhere. Long term, I would recommend to anyone both clinical or non-clinical.  Eligible to participate in Teacher Retirement System pension. 100% vested at 5 years state service - which means if you already have any state service elsewhere, it will apply here so you don’t start from zero. There is a caveat here though: see Cons.
cons:
I worked with the Office of Supply Chain managing a team of sourcing specialists. Fantastic experience. Cons? Nothing happens or changes fast here. If you are a visionary or innovator, this organization may frustrate you. The bureaucratic power structure at UTSW is for real! Also, be aware this is a state organization so you will be a state employee - consider all that goes with that. Some people like that but there are extra high guardrails compared to a non-state organization.  TRS participation is compulsory at 6.5%. Make sure you understand that going in. Also, payday is once per month. Not necessarily a con, but if you are used to twice per month or every two weeks - this could be quite an adjustment.

A little behind the curve on tech and analytics. Skiddish about remote working options. Old school in many ways. The suits and ties aren’t fooling anybody. It’s 2020.

job_title: Clinical Documentation Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: My coworkers were the best I've ever worked with. Hardworking, knowledgeable, sharing and supportive.  The work was interesting and engaging. Lots of opportunity for upward mobility.  Metrics are fair for someone experienced in CDI.
cons: No dedicated quiet or secure work space provided. Worked out of a bag, often had to find workplace anywhere that was available. Little response to concerns from management. No open door policy with director. Confusing department goals, no clear goals establish and when asked, goals were kept private and secret. Trainer allowed to continue to work from home, even during high demands ie: 5 new employees starting at the same time during one month and again last on, 4 new employees starting at the same time, with no lesson plan, onboarding curriculum, expectations not communicated to new hire or trainer. No work life balance. All HIM employees allowed to work-from-home full time or on variable schedule, except CDI employees. Unclear reasoning provided to explain this practice. Would have been useful especially during construction constraints on parking and physical availability within hospital building. Majority of physician communication is done via email or phone not in person, which was favored by the physicians.

review_title: If you are looking for an opportunity to learn and contribute.... here's the place for you!!
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: There's sufficient opportunity for growth, comfortable environment... opportunity to learn from peers and contribute to the overall mission of the school.  There a wide range of positions available from accountants to auditors to financial analysts, from database managers to clinical data analysts, from faculty (physicians/researchers) to nurses, IT positions, HR positions, etc.  The variations of job titles are endless.  In the financial world, there is always a need for individuals who are savvy with spreadsheets/database who have the ability to take raw data and turn it into meaning information which can be easily understood by the average person. Individuals who are analytical in thought...That's my niche!!! Exposure to department/clinical environments (learning about patient care, payor mixes, managed care and physician productivity (RVUs) or Fund Accounting...(state funds, grant funds, gifts, endowments, private contacts)  As a Senior Financial Analyst, I have the ability to incorporate my ideas in information that is being share with upper management... in addition to being able to show information deprived from raw data (HR or financial or clinical) in a way that has never been presented before.
cons: There's not a lot of flexiblity with raises as it is regulated by the state.  In order to see at least a 10% increase with a given year, you would have to receive a promotion.  On average, raises range from 3-4%.

review_title: UTSW Lacks Progressive Business Management Thinking and Thinkers
job_title: Non Exempt Employee in Dallas, TX
pros: Healthcare benefits and super kind intelligent caring  physicians. Great nonexempt workforce, although they are highly undervalued.
cons: Poor Managers, cutthroat supervisors, bickering between departments, bad software systems that cost ten times the money in hourly wages to use them because they do not work properly. They load more and more responsibilities onto lower paid employees, remove even minimal "perks" in order to "save" money when they literally could be saving money in SO MANY areas because there is not stream lined high level processes or teamwork  and do not even remotely understand that without their loyal "worker bees", that EVERYTHING will fall through the cracks. In some departments you are treated like you are just a number and in most of those departments they are incapable of keeping  quality employees. You don't become fully vested for ten years and it is mandatory that you contribute 3% to the TRS system. NO employer has a ten year vestment period!

review_title: Avoid this place if you are an RN
pros: TRS retirement is great, good dental benefits-this is really just par for the course, but I need to meet the 20 word minimum. New hospital (i guess this could be a pro).
cons: The retirement is good, but the way they treat you will leave you so depressed that you won't stay long enough to retire. They pay is sub-par as far as other hospitals in the area. You will have a long commute to work, because it is near downtown and you won't be able to afford living downtown. That brings up the parking fees they deduct from your paycheck. Extraordinary high patient load - a disaster waiting to happen. Managers play favorites. If you go above and beyond, it only shows them that you can handle heavier patient loads. They'll give you 3 or 4 difficult patients and their favorites will get 2, maybe 3 easy patients. No potential, because managers quickly squash any competition they see up and coming.

pros: In terms of biological research, Excellent research center with world-leading scientist. If you are ambitious in scientific career. This is one of the best places to go. It also offers the best residency program, low cost tuition, high-quality education.
cons: If you are MD or medical student, UTSW is no braine choice. However, if you are biology postdoc researcher, it is very likely that your life will be miserable. I am not blaming UTSW, the same thing happens in every University.  The key factor is to pick a good supervisor. A good supervisor will lift you up; A bad supervisor will ruin your life. But it somehow depends on your luck. Many professors pretend to be nice at interview. But after you join the group, the evil side will be revealed. Low salary for non-tenure track faculty.   Nowadays, it is much more difficult to land on a permanent job. The faculty position is very competitive, 10% postdoc researcher eventually can become independent investigator. Since the spring of biological industry has not come yet, the rest of the postdoc reseachers cannot find job in company either. just stuck in school with low salary and very long working time. completely no life. This might be changed 20 years later. Is it too late for us?

review_title: Very Good if you are looking for job-safety
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Dallas, TX
pros: Very good health insurance, no premiums for employee / affordable if adding family.  Very good job safety, as in most government jobs.   UTSW keeps growing/expanding at a very high rate, giving you many more possibilities of subject matter as well as locations.   Despite all the cons, I would still recommend this company,  with the caveat that it can be great or bad, depending where you land.
cons: Do not read the policies handbooks, rules exist but in reality everything, from getting a good raise to work-life balance will absolutely depend on your department's culture.  In some places promotion from within is pretty good, in others nearly  a forbidden word.  In fact, WHERE you end up working at UTSW  will have much more effect on your life than any UTSW-wide policy management may issue.  Most training offered is superficial compared to other state universities.  The current culture seems to be "rules apply, and will affect your job, only depending who/where you are in the totem pole, whom do you know, your boss's whim, ..etc.." .  Disheartening!    Upper management seems to be making an effort to change this but it will be a hard long battle to win.

job_title: Client Service Representative in Dallas, TX
pros: The insurance is very good
cons: The coordinators are very bad

review_title: Here today.....gone tomorrow to a better place
pros: Prestige, learning experience, and ability to interact with everyone.  UT Southwestern has the prestige because they have several nobel price researchers on sit.  It is a growing and well recognized medical center and they are overall a top medical facilities in the country.
cons: Too much Politics - like watching "Days of our Lives."  Everyone who you think is genuine could be fake sometimes.  The best thing to do is work hard and keep it professional.  Anything you say could be held agains you.  Whether you like to play football, etc....keep it minimal.  That's just the way it is.  There are people who work very hard and some who would don't do much, except (kissing a**) to get to the top - favoritism.

review_title: Great company, great mission, great goals...
job_title: Marketing & Public Affairs & Communications in Dallas, TX
pros: The pros exist where departments are cohesive, work together, have established an environment of trust and are able to make amazing strides towards making UTSW the best of the best that Dallas has to offer. There are so many brilliant people on that campus- it's humbling, yet energizing, motivating, inspirational...
cons: The leadership within various departments is glaringly, and unfortunately, inadequate to a fault. People in the Communications, Marketing, and Public Affairs department are all ready to jump ship at any minute. The leadership that has been hired in unfortunately has no soft skills, no hard skills, or no ANY skills as far as our entire department can discern. There are some really amazingly talented people there and they are just being hemorraghed by the onslaught of poor managing practices and weak, inadequate, petty, unskilled, ineffective managers.

pros:
Good benefits as far as the paid time off and sick time go.
Easily accessible.
Convienent for doctor appointments if you use any of them.
cons:
They're all about the money.  They have some good physicians but the greed from the top is apparent.
Unethical practices by some upper management.
Think you can't get fired when working with the state.  That's partially correct.  If they want you to leave they'll neat pick at your work, give you unreasonable deadlines, and basically harass you to death until you resign. 
Some managers don't seem to know much and depend on others in the field and the lower rank employees to feed them the answers and then take all the credit. 
You never know if your manager is in for the day.  You never see them but they check emails by phone to pretend they are on campus.  Word is they're at their other place of employment or shopping. And why doesn't their time off come out of their PTO?
Promotions?  Forget it. It's all about who you know.
Positions are filled before they are even posted.
So much more but you get the idea.

review_title: Poor Work Culture, Senior Leadership is CLUELESS
pros: Healthcare benefits? Read cons for the real inside scoop.
cons:
This institution has a no business sense whatsoever. They have 6 Nobel Laureates, but are clueless and lack caring for the business side of things. 

 Does not value internal employees which is shown by the complete lack of employee training/development and internal promotions. Employee engagement surveys consistently show poor engagement, but leadership does not address the issues.

Work is manual which is more tedious and does not allow employees to spend the time needed for the most important aspect of the job, keeping the CUSTOMER happy. 

Too much red tape to go through which should be expected seeing as how this is a government institution.  However, because it's government and it's an academic institution it's 100x WORSE! You should be weary of any positive reviews on the business side of this institution. These are probably from the politicians on the institution who politic their way around while performing minimal to zero real measurable results. If you love politics and not being rewarded for your work then by all means apply here.

They rage on about the health benefits. There's good reason for it. Due to the poor work culture highlighted by the backstabbing, manipulative colleagues and managers you will definitely feel like seeing a shrink!

review_title: Does anyone care about the HIGH turnover rate??
pros: Benefits, the department has a lot of potential but leadership ruins it for those they don't "click" with
cons: Leadership claims to want to improve employee engagement but if you speak up you will get yourself in trouble.  Promotions are give on attributes besides abilities.  The doctors don't even work as a team.  Sad place.

pros: If you can't make any decisions yourself and have to always be under an umbrella employer, are a great surreptitious suck up, a jellyfish tattletail, you will do awesome here.
cons:
How to succeed at UTSW:  if you are a bland/beige person who always does as a "superior" tells you and has no inherent personality, you will do great here. 
Never complain or bring up issues that could be improved. Remember they are always watching, listening and taking notes about you, your "attitude", the way you dress, any jokes you make, who your friends are, or if you put up a picture in your cubicle. They look to have "diversity", but the goal is to make everyone the same bland, suck up. The administrators have no idea what is going on, but get paid lots while you do the work, then they cheat you on your pay and reverse themselves on oral agreements you made prior to signing the contract. 
"Special" employees get away with whatever, but they will crucify you for doing the same.

pros: It's alright. You truly have to be invested in the investation in order to feel job satisfaction. So if what you are investigating doesn't interest you, doing an 8-5pm is not right for you. I really enjoy my work here because it combines so many modalities and although there is the bench work grind, I never stop learning.
cons: The gains you make at times may seem minimal. You have to celebrate your discoveries even if they are small, which typically they are. If you go in thinking to move mountains, that's a good out look, but don't get upset at the slow progress.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: They are willing to provide limited training for a specific need that they have an immediate need for.  The state provided benefits are slightly above average.
cons: The management structure supports upper management at the expense of rest of the department.  This, of course, undermines the organization.  Very dysfunctional management structure headed by a CIO who frankly does not care for improvement and defers day to day operations to an assistant CIO who has contempt for everyone.

review_title: Not a bad place to work, but limited in options for every career track
job_title: Financial Analyst II in Dallas, TX
pros: I really feel as if this a great place to work, lots of options once you get your foot in the door, depending on your work experience. There are options for promotion within separate departments and larger shared departments. Nice company culture, nice that you get a decent raise each year.
cons: I miss the pilot health care plan, it made it almost free for UTSW employees to receive care from on campus physicians. It was a selling point when I originally came here. They should bring it back.  Parking is ridiculous as it seems that they sell more spaces that they have. Valet hogs up most of parking in the clinical buildings.

review_title: Unable to move up or progress within the company!
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Dallas, TX
pros: UTSW pay for health benefits and I assist a team of physicians that I enjoy working for/with,this is what I consider a definite PRO.
cons: My management lacked the basic managerial skills necessary to mentor and grow people. They are all about self growth and prosperity. The overall culture of Internal Medicine seems to be very unstable and in desperate need of a revamp.

review_title: Average Office Life with Limited Growth
pros: Most employees are courteous. The medical services and basic research performed on campus are top notch; campus doctors and scientists are active in furthering human medicine and science. The health benefits tend to be good through the UT SELECT PPO.
cons: New software systems are time consuming to use and are auditing risks because the understaffed grants and accounting departments work so slowly. Takes forever to catch and fix mistakes. Upper university management is not great at steering the ship, so to say. They prioritize a cutesy campus image over actually developing functioning processes. There is little opportunity for promotion or growth if you are not faculty-level, and forget ever having your manager act as a mentor for career development.

review_title: great for training, not many career advancement opportunities
job_title: Postdoctoral Researcher II in Dallas, TX
pros:
UT Southwestern has great resources for research, many renowned scientists and a lot of opportunities for collaborations.
The administration is very efficient.
Postdoctoral Office and Postdoctoral Association are very active at representing postdocs' interests. PDA also organizes many career development events, as well as social events.
The benefits (health, retirement etc.) at UT Southwestern are also quite good.
cons:
There are hardly any opportunities for career advancement.
Coming from New York, I really don't care much about Dallas.
Like most of the hospital neighborhoods, the one around UT Southwestern Medical Center is unsafe.
The culture at the institution, as well as in the city as a whole, is "get your job done well and go home", there is not much socializing between colleagues, no sense of community.

pros: The benefits are excellent and currently, if you retire from UT Southwestern with at least ten years' service you earn health insurance at whatever cost an employee would pay. The university currently pays the entire cost for employee coverage if you are a non smoker.
cons: Internally, processes and procedures are often created by people who don't actually do the tasks and there's lost productivity as a result.

job_title: Transplant Technician II in Hurst, TX
pros: Company looks good to have on a resume, really great benefits including being part of the Teachers Retirement System and retirement after 25 years.
cons: Schedule will destroy you. Worked overtime almost every week and with on call hours you are only guaranteed 2 days off every two weeks. There is no actual schedule, if you are in the office you are responsible for any work that comes in even if it is not your scheduled day to stay late. Many people complained about the scheduling but managements attitude is that if you don't like it you can leave. The salary was very low for the responsibilities of the position, most people only last a year at the most. Veteran people want all the overtime because that is what makes the salary sustainable.

pros: the benefits here are SUPERB!
cons:
Management is more about (micro) managing and production, rather than leading and inspiring. They aren't the least concerned with empowering their subordinates or investing in their professional growth. 
There is a HUGE moral problem due to murky communication and micromanagement, and management is severely out of touch with the workflows of those that they manage. They just want you to push out the numbers. They like to brag about their veteran staff member's teenier, however I'm sure if those people could leave they would but they've been grandfathered into their positions and don't have the qualifications/credentials to move anywhere. 
No room for promotion/growth.

review_title: I love my job and my lab mates!!
job_title: Research Assistant I in Dallas, TX
pros: The atmosphere is great! Everyone is incredibly respectful and you can tell many of them are happy to come to work. Everyone is nice and definitely willing to help you out when you need so. Seems like a family oriented atmosphere and there is a LOT of diversity as I work with many people who have come from different countries and different backgrounds not to mention the talent. I love how my department's labs collaborate with others.
cons: The pay isn't spectacular but for living in Dallas, its not horrible. The key is to not be afraid to ask for what you want in the beginning. Sometimes there are some lab politics but that happens with any job.

review_title: Horrible management, little training and effective feedback and praise are not common here
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: Benefits and stability, I can't really think of anything else positive to say.
cons: Very little career advancement opportunities, management is very ineffective and promotions here are given on a time served basis rather than proven performance. Employees pay for parking ($300 a year), staff are always told there are tight budgets going on yet new physicians are always being hired (this is incredibly frustrating) and there is no proper training/education for this position. Coordinators are always thrown under the bus from their PIs who are the irresponsible ones. Don't bother going to HR for feedback or support as their job is to support management, filing for a grievance will make it difficult for you to transfer anywhere and you will even be told this.

pros: UTSW offers great benefits. Most of the staff are knowledgeable in regards to their roles. Advancement can be made up to a certain level.
cons: The Department of Ophthalmology has to be absolutely the worst place to work at UTSW. The current management is draconian and needs a shakeup. People are afraid of management and feel like the Employee Relations Representatives are not there for the employee, but instead are part of the establishment.

review_title: Do not waste your talent and time!!!
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Dallas, TX
pros: The best part of working at utsw are the benefits, vacation time, and retirement plan. You will be taken care of in that regard.
cons: Unless you are a student here or are in a position where you are contributing directly to research do not bother wasting your time and talent  with this institution. This is a government entity and the mindset of the people working here is exactly that, cheap and stupid. Things move at such a slow pace and if you take a look at the HR recruitment division you will know why. Months will go by before you hear anything, if you want an answer you need to contact the department yourself.  The salaries are low, you are not treated like a valued employee, there’s so much politics and back stabbing. If you want to build your career, advance in a company, actually earn a decent salary then take your talent somewhere else!!! I will not be returning.

review_title: Good benefits, but not a place to "grow"
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: The medical benefits are great at UT Southwestern and it's convenient to be located so close to the medical offices.
cons: The culture is very level conscious. People in higher up positions seem to look down on anyone they do not consider to be on their level. The physicians especially but unfortunately it is also that way with the senior staff here. Innovative, new, outside the box thinking is not encouraged and speaking your mind is often punished in my opinion.

pros: There is a lot of personal growth meaning skills development as well as contact development.  The benefits are very good as well.  Helping patients and fellow coworkers brings a lot of personal satisfaction.
cons: There is a high turnover rate, the managerial style is very top heavy.  What this means is normal staff lacks experience, and there are so many layers of management that there is a disconnect in communication.

review_title: Great organization for the right person
job_title: Quality Assurance Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros:
Academic medical center with excellent resources (brand new hospital and facilities), opportunities, and the chance to help make a difference in patient's lives. If you are the type of person who just wants to tackle challenges and aren't concerned with the obstacles, this is a great place.

Pay is average, but benefits are some of the best you'll find.
cons:
Government-funded, so there is some bureaucracy and the leadership/culture is a bit stale. Many long-tenured employees who are burnt out and not engaged, and it makes it hard for new employees to be energetic. 

Not many other employee perks besides benefits- parking is terrible, policies are stringent (i.e. tardy, not allowed to work from home) and it is just not a very pro-employee place to work. Some people don't care, but some do.

pros: Good benefits and ample time off. In some departments, the schedules are very flexible.
cons: Pay is mediocre. While the processes are always changing, most of the older staff are reluctant to accept or embrace the change. Also, the doctors are treated like gods. Even when the doc is in the wrong, it is still your fault.

review_title: Management needs to look into each department.
pros:
State of Texas employee benefits package.
Numerous educational classes that are offered by the university.
Centrally located in the Dallas area.
cons:
You have to ask your supervisors if you can apply for a job posting in another department.
Lots of dead weight.
Each departments supervisor makes up their own set of rules,no standard applied company wide.
Different rules for employees within the same department.
Supervisors don't allow employees to attend educational classes.

pros: Collaborative environment makes work enjoyable and productive;
cons: Few opportunities for internal advancement

job_title: Research Assistant II in Dallas, TX
pros: They are very prestigious, so it is a good boost to your resume.  The availability and quality of common equipment was excellent.  Typically, the labs have funding, so you do have the equipment needed to perform experiments.
cons: Unless you are a professor, graduate student,  or post-doc, you are treated poorly by others in the university.  Actually, sometimes the post-docs and students are mistreated as well.  It does depend on the lab that you work with to a large extent. I know employess from other labs and disciplines that were not happy working there.  You are a tool to them more than anything.  They don't treat you with respect.  Many of the professors are poor managers/

pros: Flexible hours, if you have a nice manager (if he or she lasts long enough) Benefits are reasonable.
cons: Management continues to delegate unreasonable workload, to new employees while keeping lazy people.  Long hours, low pay, and if you are on salary you are expected to put in as many hours as necessary to get the job done. The turn over is unbelievable.  Do not plan to make a career or friends at UTSW, it is a slave plantation.  Cost for parking is ridiculous and staff still has to walk a long way in good and bad weather.

review_title: Overall, a good place to work.
pros: Working in support of a mission to find cures and treatments for illnesses and diseases; provide quality, compassionate care for patients, and educate the next generation of physicians and medical professionals is rewarding and significant. The benefits are among the best anywhere, especially the defined-benefit retirement plan with vesting and retiree health insurance after 5 years of service, and there is good job security.
cons: State bureaucracy and red tape, slow to change or modernize, skeleton crew must work on holidays.  There is lots of politics going on, and women and minorities are still not in many of the top positions. It is still a white man's world here, although progress is being made.

pros: The benefits are amazing and the staff (non management) are great. The cafeteria was not bad especially if you worked at night
cons: The worst management on the planet. This place is so full of back stabbing management that is unreal. You have to pay to park your car. The rules constantly change to benefit the screw ups of supervisors. In my 25+ years of working I say this with all honesty RUN the other way!!!! I have over 150 hours of vacation and I am consistently being told that there is no one to cover me so I can't take the vacation hours that I have earned.

pros: From a scientists perspective: there are a wealth of resources here.  There are a wealth of opportunities to be involved with or contribute to high impact breakthroughs in science and medicine.
cons: More prestige, but at the same time your peers seem to be less impressed with your achievements as they would be elsewhere.  Also, the salaries seem to lag behind other places with "less prestige".  For example, doctors can make up to 1.5 to 2x at local hospitals and other clinics compared to here.

pros: Good benefits, mid-range pay depending on the department
cons: Very bureaucratic/siloed approach to operations. Difficult to navigate if you're not a part of the "culture". Not enough diversity in high-level executive positions. If you want to be comfortable and not rock the boat, this is the place to be.  If you have legit HR concerns, 90% chance you're out of luck when reporting it.

job_title: Senior Department Data Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Free insurance if you are single
cons: 15 years behind most healthcare organizations, mandatory 8 percent deducted off paycheck for TRS, poor leadership structure, very difficult to advance, no room for growth, discriminatory environment, management has no prior experience as leaders, leadership is a "Boy's Club", no training, and horrible work culture.

job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Dallas, TX
pros: The Associate Vice President that I supported was awesome. She was not a micro manager and allowed me to work independently. UT Southwestern Medical Center has great medical, dental, life, disability, sick leave, vacation leave and generous retirement contributions. You get all of the major holidays off in addition to some of the minor holidays.
cons: Too many of the regular employees abused the state benefits system for FMLA, Workman's Compensation, sick leave, etc....many have an entitlement attitude. It takes a lot to get fired from here because it is a state entity. Very frustrating for me because my employment history was in the private sector prior to excepting employment here.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: Even if you got a perfect review, the highest raise did not even keep up with the cost of the rise in medical coverage rates.  I lost money every year I stayed there.
cons: Way too political an atmosphere.  Lots of very smart Ph.Ds and MDs running around who have no idea how to manage people.  There are some truly awful departments that are toxic.

pros: Terrific insurance benefits as its a state institution.
cons: A constant barrage of ridicule day in and day out. Compliments always felt like they were given because they " had" to. Supervisors take direction from managers so if they're told by managers to punish or to compliment- they do. They are not by themselves free to make a decision.They have not earned honest respect from any of my former peers. As my peers shared many times: " you just learn to play their game". Rather sad.

review_title: Good place to do a postdoc if you are in the right lab
pros: Excellent quality of science and scientists, good benefits/retirement plan for postdoc, relatively relaxed pace for a top notch academic medical center
cons: Lack of local biotech industry, lack of networking opportunities. Lack of biomedical research related industry/university in Dallas. Work like a slave for the PI with very little reward and support for career advancement. To be fair though this can happen to postdocs anywhere! Poor track record of helping postdocs launch independent research careers. Lack of salary standards and very poor pay by national standards however acceptable for lower cost of living for the city.

pros: Great medical school with growing clinical presence in one of the major US cities.  Builds its clinical enterprise on outstanding research and great educational programs.  Overall, a very strong place for academic medicine.
cons: Compensation is perhaps a bit behind in some areas.  Cost of living in Dallas used to be a real bargain for what the city has to offer but that is no longer a recruitment advantage.

review_title: High stress, little training, meh pay
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: Good benefits and PTO. Managers approachable in Radiation Oncology. Some opportunity for growth. Innovative environment that is mentally stimulating.
cons: Environment is extremely stressful with no time to come up for air. Very little training. Everyone is miserable and confused half the time.  Auditors are hostile. Very high turnover in this department. The amount of work does not correspond with the pay. Expectations seem to change daily making it impossible to do your job.

pros: Paid individual insurance. Paid vacations. Excellent training.
cons: Doctors can be rude & greedy. They want certain patients/cases one week, then they don't want to those specific cases anymore.  The managment is intimiadated by the docors therefore place intimidation on the employees. To even be considered for another position, or a promotion you have to be "OK'd" by your current manager to be able to apply. You have to pay for your own parking. (around $250/year)

job_title: HSIR Technical Role in Dallas, TX
pros: State job, so very stable.  Very little (if any) work stress. Great work live balance and schedule flexibility.  Everyone is nice, and teamwork is encouraged by management.
cons: The usual: executive management out of touch, middle management (in my department) not very experienced or mature in their roles.  UTSW should invest in their managers by requiring some minimal management training.  One team manager was not knowledgeable at all on the basics: how to address inappropriate behavior of his employees, what the HR requirements/processes were, how to deliver a performance review, how to conduct effective meetings, or how to maintain appropriate confidentiality.

pros:
Work with some of the smartest people you'll even meet and learn a lot from them. 
The benefits are average.
cons:
Almost impossible to be promoted. They are very inflexible when it comes to the dress code, employee schedule and telecommuting. 
Every employee must pay for parking up to $37 per month.  Very few perks - even coffee is not provided.  Most of the buildings are very old with terrible facilities. 
The employee evaluation process is not standardized on the organizational level, so managers make up whatever they want however they want.  The salary is not competitive.  For educational institution they sure don't encourage their employees for further education.  The tuition reimbursement is a joke.

job_title: Clinical Staff Assistant in Dallas, TX
pros: Great learning experience, patient interactions are meaningful, you have the opportunity to truly help people get what they need. The doctors are pretty amazing.
cons: The work expectations will quickly outgrow your pay scale, it's extremely difficult to move up in the company, sometimes there is great hostility,most of the time the people that move up are the ones with the least amount of responsibility and education, management prefers to bring in external consultants to ask questions rather than listen to the employees that have been there years.

review_title: Horrible! Worst Workplace! Ratings should be Zero!
pros: Benefits and PTO. Doctors convenient if you use them there.
cons: Highly Political. Terrible budgets. No raises. Run by incompetent upper management who lied about many things. Dept. Manager was inconsistent and unfair. Treated people differently within the small dept. Slackers & butt kisser rewarded. Hard workers punished by being forced to do menial work that slackers refused to do. Slacker was allowed to 'work from home' which was totally against all HR policies! Others of us were worked to exhaustion and refused any comp time. Slacker was always out of the office on Mondays & Fridays playing golf while claiming to work 8 hrs. regular time & being paid!!!

review_title: It is who you know vs. what you know
pros: If you have right connection, it can be a great career $
cons: Shift to DMAIC, simplistic approach to real problems, putting emphasis on MBB and BB vs. core engineering is huge mistake.  If you are not in with the right group, you may quickly find your director you report to has half your experience and education.  I have seen people move up to director position in fields their education background does not support.

job_title: Research Study Coordinator in Dallas, TX
pros: The best thing about UT Southwestern is the location and the benefits. The location is centrally located, so it is easy to get to and from home and work. The medical, dental, 401K benefits are fantastic!
cons: The most prevalent downside to me is that there is little to no room for growth once you have a position. It is hard to get a job in the UT Southwestern system as an already established employee. I have found that they prefer to recruit from outside of the organization.

review_title: Good Place to work, with GREAT benefits
pros:
Free Health insurance
Great Pension plan & state employee benefits
Room for growth if your willing to bounce departments
Friendly co-works
Good education opportunities 
Great RN pay if you come in with experience
I would take my family here any day
Stroke care
cons:
Management doesn't usually listen to you
Slow at changing process that need updating
Enact processes that are good on paper but no fully thought out in practice
Great RN pay if you come in with ex
Preceptors do not always have much experience 2 years or less sometimes
No Trauma

review_title: Great benefits if you can endure the political strife.
pros:
Great benefits package.  One of the few places in Dallas that have a true pension plan.
Generous vacation plus sick time.
Employer subsidy of rail pass with unlimited rail travel for $38/year.
cons:
Very poor intercompany communicaiton.
Many many very big IT projects in the works without approrpriately trained employees to implement.
Very territorial acadmic organizational structure.
Fractious relations even within departments where academics are competing with each other.
Very poor long term planning.
No incentive plans for employees.

job_title: Health Systems Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Excellent Work-Life balance. People are laid back and overall very friendly. The mission of the organization is excellent and really gives one something to believe in. You really are helping other people by working here. Medically speaking UT Southwestern is a great place.
cons: The environment will suck the career ambitions out of anyone. The Health System Upper Management in IS is very arrogant and came to UT with no health care experience. They only focus on metrics and numbers while having no strategy or leadership value. As result the entire organization has no morale or direction.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Dallas, TX
pros: Great institution for basic research.  Tons of faculty with diverse interests and access to some of the best facilities and equipment available.  Relatively high stipend and relatively low cost of living in Dallas compared to other major cities makes quality of life above average.  No undergrads.
cons: Far from the coasts where most of the biotech/pharma industry is.  Makes it difficult to forge contacts within industry.  Without an undergrad population, teaching experience is non-existent if that is important to you.

pros:
Pay, Medical Benefits, PTO including sick days, vacation days, Holiday pay, good work hours 

I was able to have a great work life balance.
cons:
Poor management, lack of training but was very nit picky about my work performance ( I was new to the medical field and only there a month or two). I was looked down upon if I didn't perform to their standards. If I had better management and training I believe I would have succeeded in my role. 

I was not in this role very long because I could not take working another day with these people. Management insulted me from the beginning and did not take ownership of their poor management style. This was definitely a sick or swim environment. Only go into this role if you have years worth of experience in the medical industry.

review_title: Good benefits with dissapointing pay & subpar culture
job_title: Business Operations Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros:
-Healthcare is free for employees
-Fairly generous time off: vacation/sick time accrual is separate (8 hours a month of each plus floating holiday)
-Good name recognition that comes with employment there
cons:
-EXTREMELY frustrating culture. A huge majority of employees have been there for over a decade, so the age demographic is older, and as a result, very resistant to change
- In addition, the 25 years+ employees that fill administrative roles feel VERY entitled to make your experience as negative as they so please and completely ignore workplace manners. My coworkers and I experienced: being asked if we were pregnant when wearing a loose shirt, questioned for not wearing stockings, frequent office visits for the purpose of "checking to see if you're all working", etc.
-Exempt and non-exempt all employees have to clock-in and out
-Absolutely 0 consideration for remote or work-from-home options (even though the health systems across the street both do)
-Getting a raise/promotion is an act of Congress. They say they have to post every job publicly, interview other candidates, leave the job posted for a specified amount of time, etc. before you can be considered because it's a state institution
-Salary is significantly below the market. My dept.'s initial desired salary was $20K lower than the avg. for my role in Dallas. They ultimately offered me more than initially stated but still $5-$10K below the market and the work I performed was FAR more than they advertised
-Soo many people are "grandfathered" into this organization. UTSW refuses to fire dead-weight employees, and as a result, the hard-working, motivated employees quickly lose steam & ultimately decide to leave (all of the new hires in my group left at the 1 year mark largely due to this, and compensation reasons)

pros: Benefits, as a UT system employee, are good. Reasonable amount of vacation and relatively inexpensive health insurance.
cons: Life at UTSW varies greatly by department. Radiation Oncology is an absolute mess. Low pay, ever higher demands, extremely poor morale across the board -- just about everyone wishes they worked somewhere else. Turnover is extremely high for a reason. Suggestions to improve are always shot down, frequently with the suggestion that you go work somewhere else. Micromanagement (by managers who don't actually know what they're doing) is the usual management style. Senior management spends extravagantly on stupid stuff but pinches pennies on anything relating to the employees.

pros:
Great scientific environment
Difficult to move within the structure from postdoc to staff Research Scientist
Access to student benefits: gym, student health
Great benefits
cons:
Not good support for non academic career tracks, although the newly instituted Career Development Office is starting to provide this service
Not a good place to stay after postdoc. There are very few local opportunities. Nothing like the east or west coasts

review_title: Executives should act like adults and put egos aside.
job_title: Senior Administrative Associate in Dallas, TX
pros: Best reason to work for UT Southwestern are the benefits, Vacation/Sick Leave, healthcare within the facility is at 100%, Retirement plan.
cons: You pay for parking, communication amongst departments is horrible, some executives do not know how to lead, they put the dirty work on others,  several do not know how to manage employees, you must negotiate your salary before you come onboard, your raises are merely 1-3 %.  You could possibly get more if your manager/supervisor understand the merit process.

pros: Again, the employees here are some of the nicest people you will ever work with. People come here expecting the ship to be run by a first-class captain, but will quickly learn that it is run by a deck-hand in a suit.
cons: The leadership has poor management skills. They treat you like a position and not a person. This is a very stagnant work environment. Don't pass up the opportunity to work here if you don't have anything else on the table, but if you do, take your other option.

pros: Doctors are dedicated caregivers.  Good departments.  Health insurance is good.
cons: You pay to park and it's expensive.  No free parking anywhere unless you are a doctor.  Non-flexible work hours.  Micro management abounds in middle management for administrative workers.  HR reps are a JOKE.  Do not trust them, you would not trust a rattle snake.  Low salary.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: Pension, PTO, Central location, co-workers are friendly.  New equipment.  Ample parking.
cons: Exempt employees who work in HSIR have to clock in and are expected to log a weekly average of 40 hours on campus.  Off campus hours do not count.  Work is given to you in two week sprints.  Daily updates are required.  Limited flexibility in choices.  This may sound desirable to leaders but as an analyst you will feel little more than an assembly line will worker just without overtime pay.

pros: Having worked at UTSWMC looks great on a CV. The health benefits and retirement are good at this point, but we will see how that goes in the future. Access to the library is one of the main reasons that I stay here. For teaching and/or research, the library holdings and the library staff are the very best!!! For teaching, we have incredible clinical sites--Parkland hospital, Children's Medical Center---you can't beat that! If your program/office is on the main or north campus, the facilities are new, clean, and with all sorts of resources such as places to eat, relax, or shop while not in your office/work space. Many activities go on constantly; grand rounds, teacher effectiveness classes, and chances to mentor and teach outside your department are there if you look for them (STARS program). Campus is easy to access unless you live on the east side or east of Dallas. Many opportunities exist for educational (as well as clinical) research. Job security is good here--another reviewer said that you have to just about murder somebody to get fired and I would have to agree with that. Excellent transportation system in Dallas and UT employees get a discount on bus/rail passes. Campus is very close to Love Field Airport and reasonably close to DFW Airport with public transportation available to both.
cons: All faculty and staff must pay for parking. The neighborhood surrounding the campuses and hospitals is unsafe. Considering my teaching experience, expertise in my field, seniority, professional activity, and degrees achieved, my salary is rather poor compared to coworkers in my department. UTSW is still a conservative "good old boy" institution and it seems that some employees receive perks and raises by being pals  and "yes-men" to the department heads. Our employee evaluation system has been subjective at best, and "friends" of the department head receive the larger raises and desirable assignments, regardless of qualifications and ability. Raises have been almost non-existent, even for promotions. "Free" days off or "working from home" days are rewarded unevenly and generally only to the friends of the department head. If you want to perform formal research, you will pay your own expenses (statistician, editor etc.) in our department. Research is not promoted in our department and is not rewarded by administrative support, salary or perks. I agree with the other reviewers who said that HR and even the deans turn a deaf ear to pleas for fair practices--in fact, have seen a couple of employees eventually lose their jobs by going to them. For a university, I have been very surprised at the conservatism, fear of progress, and lack of forward thinking in my department. Also a surprise is the infighting and lack of ability to agree on anything between the physicians. Some great egos reside here.

pros: Room to grow, opportunities to learn, merit based promotions. I've been lucky to get promoted every year I've been here so far, and have been recently offered a fantastic opportunity in another department that is a huge leap for my career. Benefits also cannot be beat.
cons: Same as the pros--these all vary depending on what team you land on so it is not consistent across the campus. Also, while you'll be promoted by merit, it's really difficult to get fired so some bad workers just waste space and make your job harder.

review_title: Great place to start a career in biomedical sciences.
pros: UTSWMC has some of the best biomedical researchers in the US. Although the quality of postdoctoral training may vary based on the PI, the institution provides a great, competitive environment. Generally the labs are well funded, well supported and provide plenty of opportunities to excel.
cons: The compensation packages are "OK". Most postdocs are paid by the NIH recommended scale. Most of the labs are very competitive, so expect to spend between 70-80 hours in the lab every week.As with any state employer, there are no performance based incentives or perks.

job_title: Guest Services Representative in Dallas, TX
pros: Your the face of the company. It feels great to be able to change someone's attitude with a simple smile. Great people to work with and awesome benefits.  Pay is good for entry level employees.
cons: Getting a check once a month.  If you don't know how to manage your money you will learn.

review_title: GREAT care and retirment benefits, but not the best company when it comes to compensation.
pros: retirement, good healthcare, and alot of PTO given as your years with the company increase.
cons: Overworked in most offices, always understaffed due to budget restrains, and very low annual increases given to the majority of the employees.

pros: Health Benefits, location, retirement, parking.
cons: Where to begin.  Pay is below national average. Some departments are not bad, others have personality disordered people allowed to run the department with impunity. Bullying culture is a given even in administrative departments.  Higher ups allowed to abuse subordinates.  If superior gets reported, their superior promotes them.  Claims to be "anti-bullying" partnering with Workplace Bullying Institute but when bullying is reported an 'investigation" is done in the department.  Hence, nothing happens.  The bully is allowed to continue.  Until the Anti-bullying bill becomes law, UTSW will continue to turn the other way and turn over will be high.

review_title: It all depends where /who u work for
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Dallas, TX
pros: Great health coverage (no premium if single), good coworkers
cons:
All depends in what department u work at. Some use/abuse their employees demanding completion of impossible workloads.   Other Directors provide flex schedule, summer Fridays short schedule; even at least one had a policy in certain div of "as long as ur work is done" u could leave earlier if needed.
Mind u this is not what the university provides as alternate workday/schedule but if ur boss wants/cares she/he can make it happen.

review_title: Laid back culture, legacy systems show it.
job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Dallas, TX
pros: My immediate department has a laid back culture. I get great praise for the work I do, and I really feel appreciated.  My manager is down to earth, and appreciates that for an employee and the organization to be successful, everyone needs work-life balance.
cons: I'm bored with my work after just under two years, old mainframe systems lack data integrity.

job_title: Research Assistant II in Dallas, TX
pros: Benefits are great, good mix of students, post docs, and principle investigators.
cons: Work issues favor the employer instead of the employee. If superior goes against policy, they blame the employees. If multiple employees have same experiences of poor management, superior gets a slap on the wrist or just a warning even if multiple events occur.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Dallas, TX
pros: Competitive pay, great but expensive benefits.  Great state pension
cons: Not much support for floor nursing staff.  Nurses here are expected to pick up the slack for every other department.  Draw bloodworm, transport patients, pick up trays, clean up rooms and take out laundry.  It makes for a crazy day when you are trying to care for patients.  Many floors are now also doing mandatory call.

review_title: Awesome people to work with but find another job
job_title: Animal Care Technician in Dallas, TX
pros: Fun co-workers, honestly that’s all, there are not any other pros but I have to type 20 words at least lol
cons: Okay pay but, you HAVE to pay to park, you HAVE to pay into retirement fund that is only accessible if you stay employed with UTS for 7 years) . No holiday pay, will be compensated for your time with vacation time.. seems unfair.

pros: Good benefits, good work-life balance. Close to hospital and clinics. Convienient for doctors appointments if you need them. Easily accessible.
cons: Poor upper management, HR does not listen to constructive criticism. Lots of politics and management likes to create drama. People who do the talk and tell management what they want to hear get the promotion, not based on real contribution.

pros: UTSW is a great place to work for. As being a research assistant you do what you like and keep learning as your main job. Meet like-minded people. It’s a great academic research institute, and I’d love to work there.
cons: To become a research assistant is great, but you need to love it. I really think there is nothing negative about the institute,

review_title: Bureaucracy rules, so arbitrary change is the norm.
pros: Great health insurance from day one.  Because it is a state institution, it seems they can't fire you very easily.  This is evidenced by sub-par people in non-medical positions who just sit at their desks all day, never trying to solve any problem they don't have to.  If you're that kind of slug, this may be the desk-job for you.
cons: It depends on your department.

pros: Good benefits, competitive pay, good work life balance.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy within the University. Movement is very slow to get things accomplished. Once hired at a given pay grade it is difficult to advance. They will hire someone from outside the University at a higher pay than current employees with a proven track record.

pros: Overpay unqualified employees, employees that have stayed do not have much on their plates or any accountability.  They just backstab and eat their won.  Good advancement opportunities for unqualified personnel - good people don't stay long enough for promotions.
cons: Horrible culture from the top down.  Place full of hostility, discrimination and harassment.  Benefits keep dropping.  Constant openings, high turnover, employees are attacked publicly, no training, fear driven environment, lack of innovation.  Company too big to fail.

pros: Great for educational purposes/learning new things. Pay is mediocre, but sick time, PTO, and insurance are great. However, in outpatient we stayed so busy I could hardly use the PTO.
cons: Management is awful. Incompetent would be a compliment. Turn over is high on the outpatient side because everyone is overworked and no one feels management is on their side.

job_title: Research Technician II in Dallas, TX
pros: You are in an environment surrounded by some of the best researchers in the field. Sometimes you can have a very lenient lab where the time you come in doesn't matter, only the total hours worked a week.
cons: Extremely high expectations, with no desire for you if you're not determined to get a PhD or go to Medical school.

pros: The benefits are wonderful.  Some of the people are nice....others are mean and snooty.
cons: I've figured out that this is a who you know business. Regardless of how much time you put in it generally has no ground. Alot of the policies are STUPID!!!

job_title: Medical Center Project Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: World-renowned medical center; work closely with experts in medicine, research, and education; many tools to be successful in your job; great willingness to keep up with current trends; strong commitment to quality
cons: Limited transparency with subtle but active cronyism; limited support for employees over 50; current management efforts underway to improve employee engagement and communication.

pros: Insurance is a plus and working in many different areas getting to spread knowledge. Management just focuses on limiting your progress.
cons: Self-centered management. No chance in promoting. Employees have no say in direction of department or able to accept opinions of progress. No care for the employees and defiantly will work them much as they can. Salaries at 40 hrs a week but required at least 50hrs of work. What's ok for some is not ok for others.

pros: Great health insurance and benefits. Dart Bus or TRE passes subsidized. Lots of free lunches during informative lectures. Flexible hours! Annual reviews to address issues with supervisor(s). Salary was increased based on cost of living.
cons: Tiered system so little room for advancement and salary increase. The salary was capped at maximum of 1-2% increase per year. Promotions are based on time you are with them and not based on experience.

pros: Benefits—paid medical insurance, no weekends and paid holidays in ambulatory.
cons: Poor culture: lack of true leaders in management positions, do not promote from within, no transparency, little (if any) opportunity for growth. Poor career ladder, if any, in departments . No leadership accountability.

review_title: Great systems. Poorly support in education administration
pros: Great benefits, lots of training, great opportunity to meet departments, great students, great staff, lots of growth opportunities and opportunity for advancement
cons: Lack of development for management staff, underbudgedted school administration, high departmental turnover. Human resources department aren't supportive of employee feedback but provides more support to management versus employee feedback. HR is not for the employee

pros: I loved working for ut and hate thst i had to move because i couldve seen me working their till i wanted to retire its an amazing enviroment and always room to grow the other employees were very friendly and has pride and giving their patients the best care
cons: I really cannot think of any cons thats how much i loved working here

review_title: Excellent place to develop as a research scientist
pros: Offers a unique postdoctoral experience to a purely academic institution and fosters abundant collaboration between both scientists and physicians. UT Southwestern offers excellent access to patients for clinical research and has some of the premier research facilities in the nation.
cons: As a postdoctoral scholar, you may have limited access to your advisor.  Many lab directors are also clinicians and spend time during the week working directly with patients rather than in the lab.

pros:
- Challenging projects
- Part of an educational environment
 - Exciting to be part of a medical research facility-
- Good retirement program and benefits
cons:
-Seems to be lots of red tape
- Moves slowly on changes
- Sometimes very confusing policies and procedures
- A little frustrating when there is not a for-profit mentality

job_title: Research Assistant II in Dallas, TX
pros: UT Southwestern has great people working there and a very positive environment. There are many departments/specialties that work together to provide exciting research collaborations. The benefits are great and there is good job stability.
cons: Some faculty expect graduate student or post-doc production out of 9-5 hourly employees, which is not feasible as many post docs/students work 8+ hours a day and weekends.

pros: Great benefits, helping patients; esp. the geriatrics were the most rewarding. I also worked with a few hard working employees giving everything to help change peoples life.
cons: Work, family/life balance none existent. The place is run by good ole boys. Nepotism is rampant. HR system is very slow, it takes a year before they contact you. Most of the employees are very lazy.

pros: Great benefits because it is a state job. Great environment to work in with very smart individuals and people dedicated to serving community.
cons: High turnover rates due to mismanagement and micromanagement. It really depends on what department you work for and the attitude of upper management. Review the turnover rates for the Department you are thinking of working for and that will really help you decide.

pros: Good benefits, healthcare and dental
cons: No consistency, departments do not work together, support staff are treated as if they are two levels down from an imbecile, lots of bullying from pseudo managers.  Support staff are expected to bear the brunt of anything that goes wrong.  Lots of lazy uninspired workers.  Would not recommend to friends.

review_title: Great benefits, low pay, difficult to advance
job_title: Clinical Data Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Great benefits (medical, dental, vision, retirement acct), great access to a variety of medical services, lots of CE and training opportunitities.
cons: It seems like everyone I speak to (except upper mgmt) feels underpaid, annual raises are low, not really much room for professional growth or advancement. I feel like its an environment that tries to keep its employees exactly where they're at for the rest of their lives.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Irving, TX
pros: Good Medical Benefits. Employee medical is free just need to pay for dependents and/or spouse. Pay isn't the worst but it could be better.
cons: Management needs a drastic makeover.  There is a do as I say not as I do mentality. Management fails to realize that good employees are hard to come by and will move on if they are not appreciated.

job_title: Patient Referral Coordinator II in Dallas, TX
pros: Overall UTSW is a good place to work at. You are provided free health insurance for yourself. You also get receive a decent amount of vacation/sick time
cons: It gets a bit overwhelming to do everything that's expected as a patient referral coordinator. You are expected to take calls, contact patients that have been referred via fax/website as well as making sure medical records are received all while receiving call after call - feels like a call center mostly.

review_title: Proceed with caution, have other job options available when you start, and make no mistakes!
pros: Great place to work at as everything is self-contained and inter-connected. Great benefits and great people to work around as most everyone is fairly intelligent and career-oriented. Long-term stability if you make it beyond the 6-month probationary period. This is in an industry that is nearly insulated from the economy. Convenient to utilize internal Doctors and medical resources without leaving the campus. A very youthful environment where many folks are either starting Medical School, working on their Residency or Fellowships, and many Nurses and Doctors around the campus. Many Departments to transfer to over time, centrally located near Love Field Airport.
cons: Biggest complaint is that you are totally dependent on your Supervisor to determine your fate as to whether you stay after 6 months or are terminated within 3-4 months. If your Supervisor decides he/she does not like you for any reason, it becomes a standard routine to write you up for every petty issue or mistake, with termination highly certain. The politics at UTSW is very ugly and worse than the corporate world. During my probationary period I was treated as if I was a Contractor more than an Employee. The group I was in was the Pediatrics Dept, and take my advice and avoid this department at every angle! This is the only group that is highly dysfunctional in terms of how management treats their staff, and all of the managers are tightly connected to the HR department, so if you ever have a grievance or valid complaint while on probation you can expect no support from HR and it will actually make things worse as it did for me. Promotions are based on years of experience rather than actual skills and accomplishments. Very minimal pay raises provided if any at all. The Admin from my department had not received a pay raise in 8 years! The Pediatrics department has had 12 terminations in the last 12 months, so if you don’t fit the mold you’ll be quickly gone with NO recourse. When terminated as a Probationary Employee you cannot appeal the decision. On my way out I was told HR would include a 3rd-party independent person in the review of my case and response document in my defense, but that was totally false and they never bothered to consider my written response so I was terminated before the 90-day point. Despite many accomplishments and successes on the job, my Supervisor nit-picked everything regularly and I was written up for taking a Sick Day when I needed one. Their Job Descriptions are way too vague, and  allows too large a window for “Other Projects as Assigned”. In my case I was terminated for making common mistakes any new employee will make that were based on tasks not specified anywhere in my Job Description while learning the job the hard way, without any documentation and with a Supervisor that would only meet with me one hour per week. When I was terminated my Supervisor was promoted to a higher level despite her poor communication skills both verbally and in writing. When I asked for details in writing about projects I was working on my Supervisor always replied that if she had to put things in writing she might as well do everything herself. Finally, this place is really just an Adult Day Care Center, and good people are regularly micro-managed by boneheads who intimidate and criticize rather than facilitate your adjustment during probation or help you be successful on the job. The good people get smart and quickly transfer to another department after their 6-month stint. People were assigned to tasks outside of the scope of their jobs, such as being assigned as the temporary Manager of a group until someone qualified is actually hired in the position. IT folks are abused daily by over-demanding and uneducated users, and are not given the resources they need to do their jobs properly (most work out of a closet). If you can work within a box and like being criticized for tasks you are assigned to outside of your job scope, this is for you.

cons: No undergraduate population for those interested in teaching (or being around more effervescent characters). Not the best or prettiest part of town but that is slowly changing.

review_title: This is the worst job I ever had

review_title: Biggest mistake of my life, taking a job here!
pros: Good, fully paid health benefits.  Decent starting salary.  You practically have to murder someone to get fired.
cons: Very poor management.  I've worked in the IT Department of many other hospitals around the country.  UT has the absolute most disorganized group of management I've ever experienced.  Very political here.  If you smile and agree to contribute to chaos they'll like you, but if you even politely offer suggestions of ways to work "smarter not harder" you will be shot down so fast its not even funny.  There is very little opportunity for growth if any at all.  They claimed they couldnt get us our 1.5% raise due to budget cuts, yet they hired 15 new employees.  Management will blatantly lie to you during your interview and during the time you are employeed.  Forget having a family, social life, or any other obligations in life, this place will work you to death if you are salaried.  I'm in an employment contract because they paid for me to relocate here.  Wish they had been honest about the job description, I'd love to leave now but cant.  I've heard they hire people from out of state because they have a bad reputation in Dallas and cant get anyone to work for them.  Management will never tell you what the expect of you, never train you and basically never communicate with you.  If you want a place to slack off and get by this is it, if you want a real career with advancement and a good work environment, please by pass this place!
